asset.about: Suggestions Brad Arthur has lost the dressing room have sparked an emotional response from his players.
asset.body:
Furious Parramatta players held an honesty session to address rumours Brad Arthur had lost the dressing room, vowing to earn the wins required to take the pressure off their coach.

As soon as reports emerged this week that Arthur had fallen out with his charges, Brad Takairangi posted a link to the offending article on the players’ group chat. What followed was a frank exchange between the squad in which the players backed Arthur and took responsibility for the Eels’ poor performances.

The players subsequently gathered at their training headquarters at Old Saleyards Reserve, away from the coaching staff, to address the issue.

“It’s stupid,” Clint Gutherson said of the Arthur speculation.

“One of the boys saw it on Instagram and put it on the group chat.

“Everyone was furious about it because it’s a lie. He has got so much respect from all of the team and staff and the club. Someone’s just writing that just to get some hits or something.

“It’s absolutely stupid.

“We spoke about it the other day. We feel for Brad and the staff, they put so much effort into us, helping us get the win and the upper hand. They have sleepless nights trying to find ways for us to win and we keep going out there and losing.

“I feel bad for him and the staff more than ourselves. We’re letting them down and they’re going into bat for us, why we’re not winning. We’re just not playing well.”

Arthur could have additional support in his bid to turn the season around. Former New Zealand coach David Kidwell has been in talks to join the club's coaching staff. Kidwell, a past Eels player, and Arthur are close from their time together in Melbourne and the addition of the former back-rower to the Eels' brains trust would help offset the loss of Luke Burt, Peter Gentle and wrestling coach Brett O'Farrell from the staff in the off-season.

The Eels opened their season with six straight losses, sparking a flurry of rumours ranging from the coach losing the team to the players turning on each other. Arthur has made a raft of changes in a bid to exact revenge on a Manly side that flogged them 54-0 just a month ago.

“We can’t have people talking about our coach like that when it’s not right,” utility Will Smith said.

“That got under a lot of the boys’ skin, that we read that sort of stuff.

“That’s far from the truth. Everyone loves Brad and the rest of the coaching staff here.

“I haven’t been at a club where the coach works as hard as he does for the team.”

Kane Evans, who joined the Eels from the Roosters in the off-season, said the side is desperate to start winning to put the rumours to bed.

“[Arthur] puts his heart and soul into everything and we haven’t been performing as players and it looks bad for him,” Evans said.

“But he’s the man.

“He’s invested so much time into us and we have to pay it back to him and the club and the fans.”

Paramatta forward Peni Terepo said there was “a lot of tension in the room” when they gathered privately to support their coach.

“That’s pretty touchy, the stuff about the coaches there, especially for Brad,” Terepo said.

“If anything else, we want to play for him and the rest of the coaching staff too, they play really hard.

“We’ve had a great couple of seasons and to see what’s come out, a lot of negative stuff like that, it does piss you off a little bit.”

Arthur dropped co-captain Beau Scott and winger Bevan French from the side that lost to the Sharks in a reshuffle that includes the return of Jarryd Hayne on the wing. Gutherson, who made a successful return from his second ACL setback last weekend, remains at fullback.

“He’s let me build my career here,” Gutherson said of Arthur.

“I didn’t really come from anything, I’d only played a handful of games, and he’s had trust in me that I would get better and what he saw would come out. It has eventually and I owe pretty much my whole career to him at this stage and am forever grateful.”

data.caption: Plenty of support: Eels stars have come out in support of Brad Arthur.

headlines.headline: Eels players slam rumours of rift with Arthur

asset.about: There is a large untapped audience overlooked by the arts establishment.
asset.body:
Sydney is to get a new theatre. In a city that has made a feature of demolishing fine theatres, this is welcome news. That it is to be in Sydney's west, which, with the exception of a small but well-designed theatre in Paramatta is not well served by performance venues, is something else to be lauded. Social media was rather sour about the fact that a licensed club in Rooty Hill is to build the theatre.

It has never been much of a secret that licensed clubs in NSW have become wealthy. A sceptical public should think about how much gambling has contributed to the arts in Europe.

Many German spa towns developed a musical life based upon wealth from gaming tables. Venice's flourishing music scene was related to the fact that much of its wealth came from the gaming tables. It built one of the greatest of the Italian opera houses and commissioned composers to write for it.

Twentieth-century dance owes a debt to Monte Carlo, which was home to an exciting dance invasion from Russian dancers and European composers. Sydney once had one of the most charming small theatres in Pitt Street, the Palace Theatre, built, alongside an adjacent hotel, by . Only the bar of the hotel remains.

I became a club convert years ago when on tour with Hamlet on Ice. We did well in Newcastle at the old Newcastle Workers Club. Our performances were broad, to fill the theatre. So was the enthusiasm of the audience, which had come without too many preconceptions, to enjoy itself and did. It made me realise there was a large untapped audience overlooked by the arts establishment.

Both the arts and the clubs need to rethink some of their attitudes to performance. June Bronhill, a star of opera and musical comedy, played the club circuit and found herself arguing with club managers who didn't think her material suited the clubs. She stood her ground on the basis that she knew what her fans expected. Barry Humphries, on the other hand, had no problems in his early career filling the largest club venue at St George's Leagues Club with an audience who often had no idea who he was.

The 20th century didn't produce many well-designed theatres because, unlike the 19th, it built relatively few. The 21st century on the cusp of advanced building developments and stage technology should be able to build auditoriums that can be transformed in size or shape at the push of a button. There is hope that Sydney will get a well-designed and adaptable venue at Rooty Hill for an appreciative audience.

Michael Rolfe is an actor, director, freelance journalist, translator and teacher.

data.caption: An artist's impression of a proposed performance arts centre being built in Western Sydney by Rooty Hill RSL.
An artist's impression of a theatre space in the $100 million dollar performing arts centre being built by Rooty Hill RSL.

data.text: George Adams, who made his fortune from running sweepstakes and lotteries

headlines.headline: Rooty Hill theatre: art and gambling have a long and fruitful history

asset.about: Mortgage Choice says it will lift the share of revenue it directs to franchisee mortgage brokers, and there will be a $30m one-off hit on its full-year profit.
asset.body:
Mortgage Choice has responded to an internal backlash by giving its franchisee brokers a bigger cut of revenue, in an overhaul of its pay model that will inflict a $30 million one-off hit to its bottom line.

The listed mortgage broker, which has faced an uprising from franchisees over its business model, , on Thursday said the average share of commission revenue it would pay to franchiesses would lift from 65 per cent today to 74 per cent.

As the franchise business model faces fierce scrutiny from a parliametary inquiry, franchisees said the changes were an improvement, which showed they had previously been underpaid by Mortgage Choice. Some brokers said the company still needed to do more to deal with franchisee concerns.

Under the changes, Mortgage Choice will give franchisees a bigger share of trail commissions, via a system in which franchisees can receive commissions based on either their new lending, or existing loans.

A key complaint of some franchisees was the need to hit a monthly $1.5 million loan settlement target in order to qualify for higher commissions.

The company did not say if the target had been changed, but said it had raised commissions  on lower "tiers," which meant brokers would receive higher remuneration for the first dollar they settle.

It aims to fund some of the increased payout by launching a program to cut its cost base by about 10 per cent.

The changes will result in a one-off, non-cash hit to its net profit after-tax for the full year of $30 million.

Full-year profits, which it will deliver next month, were expected to be between $23.2 million and $23.4 million, and next year's profit is projected to fall to $16.5 million under the changes. Its share price rose 3.5 per cent, to $1.48.

Robyn Lang, a mortgage broker with Mortgage Choice, who has lost hundreds of thousands of dollars, including the family home and retirement savings after buying an existing Mortgage Choice franchise in 2005, described the new model as proof that Mortgage Choice had been gouging franchisees.

"I am happy there will be an increase to the payments of the work I have already done but it makes no provision for compensation for the money gouged over the past eight years," she said.

"It reminds me of the French Revolution. Throw crumbs to keep people happy but at the end of the day I'm not sure it will stop the revolution."

She said under the new model new franchisees get a better deal.

It is something that riled Russell Chellew, another mortgage broker who has been struggling to make ends meet working under the Mortgage Choice umbrella. He said the new model was an improvement but on the bottom trail tier new greenfield franchisees are paid a better trail rate. "It doesn't seem fair to me when we do the same tasks," he said.

Aurelio Tenaglia, who owns a shop in Paramatta, said Mortgage Choice needed to review the franchise agreement to remove the handcuffs placed on franchisees which doesn't allow them to take their clients with them or trail book commissions. He said some key rival mortgage brokers allow brokers to leave and take their clients or commissions.

Morningstar's head of banking research, David Ellis, said the 74 per cent of revenue the company planned to pay franchisees was higher than it had expected.

Despite this, he said Mortgage Choice should be able to continue paying out a high share of profits as dividends.

Mr Ellis estimated the company's shares would offer investors a fully-franked dividend yield of about 9 per cent based on its future guidance, but acknowledged this came as the industry deals with regulatory pressure over its commission-based business model.

"They did make the point that there's a lot of regulatory uncertainty at the moment and there may be changes in the future," Mr Ellis said.

Chief executive Susan Mitchell said the new pay model would reward franchisees that expanded, while providing more certainty in weaker periods.

“These changes are the product of extensive consultation with broker franchisees and the recognition we needed to rebalance our service provision with more competitive remuneration,” said Ms Mitchell, who was appointed to the role in April.

data.caption: 'Throw crumbs to keep people happy but at the end of the day I'm not sure it will stop the revolution,' says Mortgage Choice broker Robyn Lang
Mortgage Choice chief executive Susan Mitchell acknowledged the broker needed to offer franchisees more competitive pay.

headlines.headline: Mortgage Choice profit to take a hit as it overhauls franchisee pay model

asset.about: An unconvincing Eels stumbled past a patched-up Rabbitohs and set up a week-one finals collision course with the Storm juggernaut, with Semi Radradra's hat-trick sealing the top-four spot on Friday night.
asset.body:
Brad Arthur reckons the Eels have a "free throw at the stumps" in their daunting week-one finals clash against the Storm juggernaut, claiming his side are a chance of shocking the runaway minor premiers "if we're allowed to play football".

Frustrated with a stalled ruck during Parramatta's nervy top four-sealing win against the patched-up Rabbitohs on Friday night, Arthur already staked a marker for next week's clash with the ruthlessly efficient Melbourne and cheekily railed for a speedy play-the-ball at AAMI Park.

"We're playing Melbourne and we're looking forward to the challenge," Arthur said after Semi Radradra's hat-trick inspired an unconvincing 22-16 win over the Rabbitohs at ANZ Stadium. "No one's going to give us a chance and it's a free throw at the stumps. If we're allowed to play a bit of football we're a chance.

"They're the masters at [slowing the ruck], they tackle well and they've got great systems. They're not going to beat themselves. We've got to complete and be positive with our ball movement. If you give them opportunities they make you pay."

Perhaps the gulf between the Storm and Eels can be measured by the plucky Rabbitohs, who copped a 64-6 caning at the hands of the Melbourne before a weakened side pushed the Eels all the way just a week later.

Asked about the Eels' chances in Melbourne, Rabbitohs coach Michael Maguire quipped: "After last week ... good luck. They're running red hot at the moment and unfortunately last week we were on the end of it.

"I think when you come into a finals series it starts next week for the teams. It's really up to the team that turns up ready to go. It's a really, really tight competition. If Parramatta turn up they'll give themselves a chance."

Maguire made a head-spinning seven positional or personnel changes to Souths' starting line-up due to illness and injury with captain Sam Burgess, Adam Reynolds, Angus Crichton and Aaron Gray all dropping out of the starting 13 named on Tuesday.

But for large parts the Robbie Farah-led Rabbitohs looked on the brink of one of the upsets of the season, potentially robbing the Eels of their anticipated second chance saloon.

The result condemns premiers Cronulla to either fifth or sixth spot and the prospect of winning four straight games throughout the finals to defend their title.

The indifferent Eels effort will be dissected in detail, one which hardly had the feel of a side ready to go deep into the play-offs. But Arthur will be relieved the NRL's feel-good story can at least plan to be playing over the next fortnight.

"We're happy with where we finished," Arthur said. "As I said to the boys, 'You don't win 16 games by fluke'. The performance was patchy tonight, but Souths came out and had a red-hot crack and played for their coach. It was probably exactly what we needed. Two years ago we might have thrown that away in the last three minutes."

Brothers Michael and Robert Jennings traded tries on opposite sides of the ruck and on the same side of the field in an enthralling opening 15 minutes where it looked anything like a top-four team playing against one who could be holidaying in the Top End next week.

Michael sliced through and stood up fill-in fullback Damien Cook to start what many thought would be an Eels procession, but Robert's sharp response for the Rabbitohs indicated anything but the one-way traffic it was supposed to have been.

Kyle Turner slid over after some neat work by Cameron Murray and Farah on the first set after Corey Norman's careless behind-the-back flick pass surrendered possession.

If not for Radradra darting over in the shadows of half-time - giving them a lead they scarcely deserved - the red-faced Eels may have been able to compare notes with the red-cheeked Arthur after a half-time rev-up.

If his side didn't hear the half-time message properly, they would have heard it loud and clear during the second stanza - Arthur anxiously balancing on the edge of his sideline seat and bouncing out of it for the most part.

Radradra's second - this time a simple scurry on the end of an inch-perfect Corey Norman floater - couldn't even calm the coach.

He knew why. Jennings Jnr outdid Jennings Snr when burrowing over in the corner for his second, albeit off a blatant forward pass to keep the rookie Rabbitohs within touching distance.

But Radradra's late intervention was enough. It usually always is. But will it be enough to stop the Storm?

Parramatta Eels 22 (Semi Radradra 3, Michael Jennings tries; Mitchell Moses 3 goals) defeated South Sydney Rabbitohs 16 (Robert Jennings 2, Kyle Turner tries; Bryson Goodwin 2 goals) at ANZ Stadium. Referees: Gavin Badger, Chris Butler. Crowd: 21,533.

data.caption: Upset on cards: Kyle Turner burrows over for the Bunnies.
Sibling rivalry: Michael Jennings makes a break en route to scoring.
Hat-trick hero: Semi Radradra scores despite the efforts of Luke Kelly.

headlines.headline: Paramatta Eels winger Semi Radradra's hat-trick seals top-four spot against South Sydney Rabbitohs

asset.about: Drivers will feel the difference in traffic as they travel on the newly widened M4 motorway, but in a month's time, so will their pockets.
asset.body:
Western Sydney motorists will feel the difference in traffic as they travel on the newly widened M4 motorway, but in a month's time, so will their pockets.

The NSW government officially opened the newly widened four lanes on the M4 in both directions from Homebush to Parramatta on Sunday, and while it will provide traffic relief for motorists, it comes with a price tag.

From August 15, motorists will pay a distance based toll of between $1.77 and $4.56 following a one-month toll-free period.

Tolls were removed from the M4 in 2010 but the government has justified their reintroduction insisting it's the fairest system.

"People have a free option – if people don't want to use a toll road they can use the existing roads to get to where they need to be if they are price sensitive," Premier Gladys Berejiklian told said on Sunday.

"We also make sure that you only pay for what you use.

"We are making the system as fair as possible and as affordable as possible."

However, western Sydney motorists aren't happy with the new tolls, with some saying they won't be able to afford it and will instead be forced to use the congested Paramatta Road.

"People have a choice between paying $2000 a year in a tolls or travelling on one of the most congested roads in Sydney – it's not much of a choice they're given," Opposition Leader Luke Foley said.

While the opposition claims it supports lane widening on the M4, it did not support the reintroduction of tolls on the road.

Mr Foley insists the toll should be cancelled as motorists are paying for one extra lane and not a new road.

"We have said there is a role for tolls in the overall Sydney roads needs, but it's not the case for a new toll on the M4 that people have already paid off," he said.

The M4 widening is the first completed part of the government's $16.8 billion WestConnex project.

AAP

data.caption: The old toll booths on the M4 were closed in 2010.
Drivers will get one month toll-free on the new M4.

headlines.headline: Opening of Sydney's M4 motorway to ease congestion but it comes at a price
